user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CountSemDelete:
```c
int32 OS_CountSemDelete(osal_id_t sem_id)
{
    OS_object_token_t token;
    int32             return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_EXCLUSIVE, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sem_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_CountSemDelete_Impl(&token);

        /* Complete the operation via the common routine */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(return_code, &token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_CountSemDelete:
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
int32 OS_CountSemDelete_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_count_sem_table, *token);

    if (sem_destroy(&impl->id) < 0)
    {
        return OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(int32 operation_status, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    osal_id_t final_id;

    /* Clear the OSAL ID if successful - this returns the record to the pool */
    if (operation_status == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        final_id = OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED;
    }
    else
    {
        /* this restores the original ID */
        final_id = token->obj_id;
    }

    /* Either way we must unlock the object type */
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, &final_id);

    /* Give event callback to the application */
    if (operation_status == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_NotifyEvent(OS_EVENT_RESOURCE_DELETED, token->obj_id, NULL);
    }

    return operation_status;
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no code fragments in the provided functions that assign to function parameters themselves. Summary of checks against MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8:

- OS_CountSemDelete(osal_id_t sem_id): sem_id is passed by value and never assigned to in the function. The local variable token is passed by address to other routines; modifying the object pointed-to by a pointer parameter is permitted, and no assignment to a parameter variable occurs.

- OS_ObjectIdGetById(..., OS_object_token_t *token): this function assigns to fields of *token (token->obj_idx and token->obj_id). Modifying the object referred to by a pointer parameter is allowed by the rule; the pointer parameter variable token itself is not reassigned.

- OS_CountSemDelete_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token): token is a pointer-to-const, so the function cannot modify the pointed-to object via this parameter; there is no assignment to the parameter variable.

- OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(int32 operation_status, OS_object_token_t *token): operation_status is only read; token is used to read token->obj_id and passed to other functions. The function does not assign to its parameters.

No other assignments to parameter variables were found in the provided code. Therefore there are no fragments that need further investigation for violation of Rule 17.8 in the supplied code.
